characters.description: He is found dead in his house and the narrator feels responsible for him. He wanted the narrator to get somebody for him so he wouldn't be alone.
He is found dead and someone refers to him as a 'madman'.  His suspicions of his wife are brought to light at the inquest.
He gives testimony at the inquest regarding Wilson's suspicions of his wife.
She testifies that her sister was happy with her husband and had never met Gatsby. She convinces herself of her statements and cries.
She and Tom leave early that afternoon with baggage and leave no address. The narrator calls her after finding Gatsby.
He and Daisy leave early that afternoon with baggage and leave no address.
The narrator tries to contact him after Gatsby's death, but he is unavailable. He sends a letter expressing his shock and inability to get involved due to important business.
He feels responsible for Gatsby's death and tries to contact people for him. He reflects on the events following Gatsby's death and feels a sense of solidarity with him.
His picture is in Gatsby's desk, symbolizing a token of forgotten violence.
Meyer Wolfshiem mentions to send a letter by Edgar.
